Review Text: Diyaluma Falls was one of the best trips we did in Sri Lanka. We rode to the bottom of the falls from Ella ( about 1 hour on a motorbike) wondering if we would have to carry our jackets and helmets on the hike and where to safely park the bike.  We were lucky to be greeted by Saman who took care of everything. His guided hike to the waterfalls was great. He has so much knowledge of the forest, stopping along the way to show us different trees and plants. We spent several hours working our way down the different levels of the waterfall, swimming,  rock jumping and rock sliding. The views were breathtaking and we rated it as one of the best days out on our holiday. Saman‚Äôs number is +94787784560

Review Title: Diyaluma Falls ‚Äì Where Adventure Meets Scenic Beauty
Review Text: Diyaluma Falls, Sri Lanka‚Äôs second-highest waterfall, is a breathtaking natural wonder near Ella. Cascading dramatically from lush green cliffs, it offers stunning views and refreshing natural pools at the top. A short hike rewards visitors with panoramic landscapes and peaceful surroundings. Ideal for nature lovers and adventure seekers, Diyaluma Falls is a perfect spot to swim, relax, and experience Sri Lanka‚Äôs raw beauty.

The waterfalls are beautiful and the hike is very doable. You can drive (or be driven) quite high up toward the parking area, and from there it‚Äôs another 20‚Äì30 minutes uphill to reach the top of the falls. However, compared to the many other activities we‚Äôve done in Sri Lanka so far, we found it quite busy at the waterfalls. Our tuk-tuk driver immediately became our guide, but in hindsight we regretted that a little. We were advised to take a guide so you know where to go after reaching the top, but in our experience you can easily figure this out yourself using Google Maps and by following other people. Our guide also seemed quite rushed, while you really want to spend a few hours relaxing in the natural infinity pools. Our advice: definitely go, but don‚Äôt take a guide, and make sure to give yourself enough time.

Diyaluma Falls was one of the best things we did in Sri Lanka.  Well worth the drive off the main road.  Very manageable hike to get to the top of the falls and I highly recommend going early to beat the crowds.  We were there at 9am and it was perfect.  We also had the good fortune to have Saman as our guide.  His family lives at the base of the falls and he is the expert on safety and all the surrounding flora.  He made our day at the falls unforgettable!  Great communication and was waiting for us when we arrived.  His number is +94787784560

Review Title: The best day in Sri Lanka with our wonderful guide Saman!
Review Text: We had an incredible day at the falls with our 6 year old son. Our guide, Saman, was wonderful and definitely meant we got the most out of our trip. We found Saman‚Äôs number on other reviews here and text him when we were still in Udawalawe. He agreed to pick us up from our bus in Wellawaya, drive us all the way to the falls, guide us around and then drop us in Ella when we had finished. He offered a really good price for the day. Saman was so friendly and spoke good English. He arrived early to meet us and took us to his family kiosk at the base of the falls where we were able to leave our heavy bags and change our clothes. He gave our son a coconut and then we took the Tuk-tuk further up the hill. From there it was about a 20-30min walk to the falls. On the way Saman taught us all about the plants growing by the side of the trail. He picked lemongrass and cinnamon for us so we could smell them, showed us cashew trees and rubber that had solidified from rubber trees. Our son was fascinated by all his knowledge. Saman then led us to the highest pool where we were able to swim and skim stones. He showed us safe places to slide through the rocks into the water. There are tiny fish in the water that tickle as they nibble your feet. Further down the falls we were able to jump off a 10m ledge into a deep pool below. It was terrifying but absolutely worth it if you can summon the courage. It‚Äôs also a great spectator sport if you‚Äôre not up for it yourself! Even further down Saman went and found leaves like mini helicopters which he showed our son how to throw into the wind. The view from the top of the waterfall is breath-taking. We had our favourite day so far in Sri Lanka and this was all down to Saman and his brilliant knowledge. He was so kind with our little boy and made him feel really special and cared for. We had wondered if we needed a guide and it‚Äôs definitely possible to do it without one but we wouldn‚Äôt have had such an amazing experience if it weren‚Äôt for Saman. There are places to buy fruit and little restaurants all the way up and down for food. We spent about 3 hours there and the time flew by. 10/10 for this experience. On the way to Ella, Saman stopped and bought us hot corn on the cob from the roadside. It was delicious. Thank you Saman. If you want to get in touch his number is +94 (78) 778 4560

Visiting Diyaluma Falls was one of the most beautiful parts of our trip to Sri Lanka - so authentic and breathtaking! We did the guided hike to the top of the waterfall, which was not too difficult and offered amazing views all the way. At the top, we swam in the natural pools right next to the edge of the falls - such a unique and unforgettable experience. The place felt untouched and peaceful, far away from the crowds. After the hike, they also offer an optional shared lunch, which is a nice way to relax and enjoy local food with fellow travelers.

The tour with our guide Saman was simply unforgettable! He led us to one of the most beautiful waterfalls and gave us a fascinating introduction to the native plant world along the way. We were able to get to know various spices such as pepper, cinnamon, pampero plant, gum and wild basil ‚Äì a real experience for all the senses! Saman was particularly attentive and professional. In the places where we could jump into the water, he checked everything thoroughly beforehand to guarantee our safety. He also told us that with a bit of luck, elephants and leopards can also be seen during the hike through the jungle ‚Äì which made the adventure even more exciting! An absolutely great tour that I can only recommend to anyone. Thank you, Saman! If you want to book a hike with him here his number: +94 714304910

Review Title: Unforgettable experience with Saman as our guide!
Review Text: Our trip to Diyaluma Falls was one of the absolute highlights of our journey through Sri Lanka ‚Äì and we owe that to our amazing guide, Saman! He not only led us safely to the top but also showed us hidden natural pools and breathtaking viewpoints that we would never have found on our own. Saman knows exactly which pools are safe to swim in, where it‚Äôs best (and safest) to jump into the water, and where sliding down the rocks is the most fun. He is incredibly friendly, attentive, and knows the area like the back of his hand. Saman and his family also run a charming little kiosk right next to the waterfall. No one knows Diyaluma Falls better! We can wholeheartedly recommend him ‚Äì if you want to truly experience the falls, go with Saman. Direct contact to Saman: +94 78 778 4560 (WhatsApp available)

There is a small charge to enter at the Upper Falls now.  After seeing the upper falls and swimming in the natural pools, you will want to see the beauty from below, this huge waterfall is incredible from below, being the 2nd largest in Sri Lanka.  The upper part is a hike with stairs and we got a guide as it had been raining days prior and he was worth the payment as he added a lot to our enjoyment and assisted with photos and safe places to swim even with nibbly fish.

Review Title: Amazing waterfall and plunge pool experience
Review Text: These waterfalls are amazing, our guide was Diyaluma Guide Asanka ( you can get his details from google ) He meets you halfway up and then take you by tuk tuk some way further up. Then he shows you the best route to the falls, helps you navigate the rocks and takes great photos and videos of you in the water. I think this is near the top of things to see and do so far on our travels around Sri Lanka.

Really lovely walk to top of these falls if you are sure footed, bathing was most fun where the locals were under the bigger falls (third? Pool down from top) but slippy so watch out. A fun activity with teens, just be wary of leeches, and have a king coconut as refreshment from one of the stalls on the way down

The Diyaluma Fall is one of the most beautiful waterfalls I have ever seen. The hike there is super nice and exciting, as wild elephants are traveling here. The view from above of the countryside is fantastically beautiful. We can definitely recommend the hike to Diyaluma Fall.

It's an amazing place, really. You must visit it Approximately 40 minutes drive from Ella town, this place is worth the visit. We drove to the waterfall and then paid for a guide who took us to the top of the waterfall (one-third of the way in Tuktuk and the rest on foot). You can swim up there and the view from the top is spectacular!

It takes about thirty minutes and a small fee to access the top of the waterfall from the parking lot. This effort is largely rewarded: there are several pools in which to cool off. When we went there, there were quite a few other tourists but we were still quiet. Going down to the parking level, there are many restaurants to regain strength.

We parked up our minivan and picked up our local guide who drove our group of 9 family and friends in a 4 wheel drive to the foot of the falls where there was a toilet and a snack shop. It was there we started our trek to the top. Although not a very difficult walk, our group had various degrees of capabilities and that coupled with the 30¬∞ heat and humidity did impact upon some of our party. The hike took best part of an hour to reach the top and the first pool with a natural slide. Next we moved down to another pool and the chance to take a 60 foot jump into the pool below, unfortunately only one of our group felt comfortable enough to do this. Last stop was a sightseeing break which provided amazing vistas of the surrounding area. As the sun began to set we began our journey back to our vehicle, a truly wonderful excursion and well worth the climb up and down.

We've visited many waterfalls on our travels, and this one is definitely worth the trip! It is superb, with several swimming pools for swimming. Access requires a 20-30min walk one way, but it's worth it because there aren't too many tourists and the view is magnificent. However, be careful of slippery rocks.
Its a must place to visit, there's no picture that could describe its beauty, you have to climb up the waterfall to enjoy it fully, be prepare to swim üòç

Get your driver (or drive yourself) up to the upper falls, but don‚Äôt accept a guide. They‚Äôll try to scare you but the path is clearly marked and you can ‚ÄúNo Thank you, good bye‚Äù your way past anyone offering their services unless you‚Äôre feeling generous. But on the stairs near the top is a lovely little coconut stall with two kids helping out their dad. These kids are ADORABLE and terrific little hosts. It‚Äôs worth the normal coconut fee for the electrolytes a the entertainment. This little stall made the trip for us. At the top, turn right for lower pools and view down falls, left for a more calm and safer swimming area.

You can go there alone but please consider to hire Sudu. He is a guaid tour since 2003. During COVID he had no work 3 years and need to sell tuk tuk and even a smartphone. He is a great guide and take care of you during the trip. His phone no. +94 (70) 108 5255  Have fun!
Amazing waterfalls. Really enjoyed my time here. If you are in Sri Lanka, it is a must see stop. You can swim in the waterfalls.

Without a shadow of a doubt the most beautiful waterfalls in all of Srilanka. Scenic jumps, natural pools and breathtaking views. They can be reached with a short walk of about 15 minutes. If you want, at the starting point of the excursion which is located a couple of kilometers before the bridge where you can admire the last jump, you will also find numerous locals willing to accompany you for a few euros
A must see, this waterfall is simply magnificent, majestic. In the middle of stones, trees and wild animals, this flow of water which falls from around 185m is simply relaxing.

Great swim at the top of the waterfall. The walk to this place is not for the weakhearted or the ones with no endurance. But once you are there... Amazing! You can easily stay 2- 3 hrs just enjoying yourself. Bring some food or drinks, or buy a coconot from the man who sells them there.

After a very short climb, you will be under the magnificent spell of the waterfall. The water is really cold but swimming is wonderfully enjoyable and the nature is wonderful. Before climbing the waterfall, you can drink king coconut below and watch the monkeys.

Myself and my family (two young kids), debated whether to do the local waterfall from Ella called Ravanna Falls, or to make journey to Diyaluma waterfalls. We ended up doing both but we are very glad we made the extra effort to go to Diyaluma waterfalls as they are much more extensive than Ravanna and there are multiple different waterfalls and areas to swim, and even some places to jump into rock pools. However, we could not have done this trip without a guide. We would not have known which rock pools you could jump into and how to get up and down the mountain. In addition to that the guide will usually take you the first 2 km of the journey, and then you can walk the rest (1km).  In short, it is well worth the money. We were fortunate enough to have Saman as our guide, and not only was he incredibly knowledgeable about the waterfalls, as he was from the area, but he also had relatively good level of English, so we could communicate with him. He really went above and beyond, and even carried our six-year-old daughter on his shoulders up and down the tricky bits of the path (see picture below).  Saman can be contacted on +94 78 778 4560 if you want a great guide and an unforgettable experience.

The best waterfall I have visited anywhere in the world. The great attraction is a series of linked pools towards the top that are ideal for swimming. It‚Äôs a fairly easy hike up and then a great day in the pools with some fabulous views.

Ultimately good. We hiked through the forest and reached the upper and lower Diyaluma falls. There is a natural pool. When we went the water was more. Our guide helped us to find a safe place to have a bath. He took us with passion and patience . His name is Upendra. He speaks and understand English. We parked our car near the village . From there along with tuktuk to go up and down until the hiking point. He also came with us until the falls. He can be contacted at 0775474725. Our driver got a good deal by talking with him for both tuktuk and being a guide. After bath we changed our wet clothes in his house. Friendly people. I have included his photo with his shop. The falls and the forest just got imprinted into our heart. Beautiful road to the falls and extraordinary hike upto the top of the falls. A must do. But people should restrain from polluting the place with plastics.
It is an amazing place to visit. A not to hard climb to the top‚Ä¶ but when you get there, the view and the waterfall are amazing.

Nice place, good view but from the bottom. It‚Äôs an easy access to the top but the local guides tell you that you need them as you may get lost in the jungle - not true. Just follow the crowd ;) on the top will just see ‚Äûbloggers‚Äù taking solo pictures in the basin and the rock wall of the pool painted with tourist initialls. You can leave that view out. Being caught in the rain will only get things worse.

one of the most beautiful palces in Uva province to visit. never miss Diyaluma and Upper diyaluma if you planned to visit Ella, Koslanda, Haputale, Bandarawela or wellawaya areas in Sri lanka. you will definetely have an adventerous day.

This was one of our favourite days in Sri Lanka. Definitely worth a visit. As others say below, you can go with or without a guide. We had a guide from Ella whose company we really enjoyed, so we went up with him ‚Äì but you could definitely find your way without a guide if you wanted to, maybe with a wrong turn or two along the way. We took the short 20-minute walk rather than the 2-hour hike, and didn‚Äôt regret it. The bottom pool is the busiest with tourists ‚Äì but we found it was only really worth a short stay. The views are beautiful, and this is where everyone gets their photos ‚Äì but that‚Äôs pretty much it. The second pool, a very short walk away, is good for a swim, and the view of the falls above you is pretty special. The third pool, directly above the second, and a short 2-3 minute hike up, features an 8m cliff jump. We did it and were perfectly safe ‚Äì but I wouldn‚Äôt do it without being shown by a local guide. There are plenty around the first pool who can show you. We did it a couple of times ‚Äì every time, my feet hit the bottom of the pool at the end of the jump, but not hard enough to be of any concern ‚Äì just a surprise first time around! We then had a lovely time at the top of the third pool, sitting in the sun and relaxing. Well worth a trip.

If you enjoy the process of getting to the waterfalls (hiking a bit), plunging (not for the faint-hearted) and swimming in the pools; you'd definitely relish this particular waterfall! There are many layers, the view is amazing and the water is cool and clean. The only pity is that the locals sometimes leave their trash behind so please leave only (wet) footprints! When you do get to the last part, you'd find yourself on top of the cascading water and be greeted with a stunning view of the landscape before you. I stayed a safe distance away from the edge due to my fear of heights/ falling but I was really glad that I made it out there. As with all waterfalls, tread carefully and stay safe. I'd skip Ravana Falls and pick this anytime.
Diyaluma Falls is located near the town of Koslanda on the Wellawaya Road in Colombo via Beragala. It is situated near the main road. It is second tallest  waterfall in Sri Lanka  and is 220m high.

If you don't want to get scammed 2000 rupee for a 20 min walk to the waterfall then check the location in the attached photos. This place gives free parking (the rest charge) and they have steps that go straight up to the waterfall. Just follow up, wqlk along with barbed wire on right, through a small bit of woods (wear shoes or sandles). You can hear the waterfall on right and you will probably see guides walking with paying tourists along the way... once at the waterfall go left (many ways to plunge pools further up. Please up vote this so other tourists can decide to pay or not pay. (The place on the photos also has rooms, food, snacks, cold water etc - they are very nice family).

We stopped by the waterfall and it looks stunning from the bottom. But even better was to go up with one of the local guides - they drove us by tuk tuk and then brought us to the top of the waterfall (15 minutes walking). We could swim there in lovely natural pools right above the fall! :)) It was such fun! We took many pictures, then he took us to another swimming area and showed us where is it safe to jump into the water (we didn't, it was like 8 meters jump! :D). The only thing you need to be careful of is the water quality (not pure) - you might get ear aching if you dive - clean your ears afterwards. The contact for our guide: Mr. Sudu, 070185255 - he speaks good English. ;)
Try one of the older roads in Sri Lanka from Wallawaya to Haputhale through Koslanda and you will see Diyaluma on your way.

Diyaluma situate beside Beragala Wellawaya rode 6Km away from Koslanda. If you need to use, public transport also possible to reach this place. Once you reach there, you can climb up few steps up if water level is law. There is a pool up there. But be careful to bath there, better not to. It's sleapery also.

We rented a scooter in Ella and took the 1 hour ride (1:20 to the top) to visit the magnificent waterfall. On the food of it you can take a climb to bath in the pools below the fall. After it you can take another 20 minutes on bad roads to the top. Place your scooter there (100 rupies) and walk over (40 minutes) to the pools to chill. Definitely recommended. It is a day trip. On the food of the waterfall you can buy water. Bring your food :)
It is the second highest waterfall in sri lanka. On the up, woow thats the place.. #naturalpool #hiking #chilling #camping

The Diyaluma falls is the second largest waterfall in Sri Lanka and it's looks very fashionable on water getting down from up Hills. Travelers can view the waterfall from the road. The lost of Monkeys around the waterfall.
Normally we like to go things alone but I suggest getting a guide who can take you to the places to swim (and jump if you desire!) and for good photo shoots.

Stunning waterfall!!  We hired a scooter from Ella and ventured here. At the base guides will try and offer services to the top. This is easily achievable without their services if you are adventurous. They said a scooter will not make it to where the climb starts, we made it with ease. The trek is somewhat difficult depending on fitness. Would allow minimum 3 hours round trip. But more would be preferable. We spent 4 or so up and down

We took tuk tuk from haputale 3500lkr Driver waited on us, however we came back down same way as went up, he was apparently waiting on other side... So make sure you clear this up.. Good 20min walk up to top of falls well worth it what a view. You won't need a guide path is pretty obvious.. Neraby Town is quaint stop for a nosey around locals are friendly

Today we visited the amazing diyaluma falls. For this trip we stayed in the nice town Wellayama, from this place it's a short trip (20 minutes by tuktuk) to the diyaluma falls. Wellayama is located 40 minutes from Ella and easy to travel from or to the national parks in the south. From this town it's also verry easy to visit the buduruwagala rock temple (360Lkr) wich is verry beautifull and not touristic at all! We stayed at Bindu Homestay and i can higly recommend this place. It's a verry friendly family and he also has his own tuk tuk and car to bring you to all places you want. They will do everething to put a smile on your face, they are great!

We drove to the bottom of the waterfall by car, it‚Äôs beautiful to see. Lots of people just stop there ....... not us! We then took a tuk tuk as far as possible as the road becomes non-drivable. The tuk tuk driver became our walking guide to the top of the fall and to another hidden waterfall you cannot see from the road. The hike is approx 30-40 minutes with varied difficulty. Honestly do it!! Wow wow wow it is just simply stunning. There were no tourists up there, when we went, only local kids and us swimming and playing in the falls. One of my favourite experiences of Sri Lanka and travelling the world. So so lucky to have such an experience

Amazing view and experience ! Would highly recommend to take a Tuk-Tim WITH GUIDE to reach the top of the waterfalls. Several tuk tuk drivers are trying to sell you their service but we would definitely recommend to go to the small and lonely family shop which is on the left handside when looking at the waterfall . Their son, Tharindu (0719702456) is such a lovely person . He took us to the waterfall and took great pictures . So nice and genuine person!
Beautiful place worth a visit. At the beginning you will expect a climb of about 45 min, but it is worth it! Views, small waterfalls and lakes are perfect for swimming. This place has enchanted us!
It is worth the trek to get here both walking the and tuk tuk here. We ended up spending 3 hours here enjoying the rock pools and waterfalls. You must come here

Wow. Could not recommend going to Diyaluma Falls more. It was an absolute highlight for not just our trip to Ella, but Sri Lanka as a whole. Such a beautiful waterfall, amazing views, you can swim (definitely recommend as it‚Äôs a lot of fun!) and the hike isn‚Äôt too hard to get there. The only thing is, you do need a guide to walk you to the spots to go. When you arrive by tuk tuk, there will be guides there that will offer their service, at first you don‚Äôt think you need them but I‚Äôm telling you... you definitely do. So many turns and there‚Äôs no clear path in the slightest, and they take heaps of photos for you ! We went with a guy named Dennis (071 988 1825 if anyone wants to get in contact with him) and he said we decide on a price at the end depending on how happy we were with his service. We ended up paying 2,000 rupee for 3 of us which I think is very reasonable. Also, a tuk tuk from Ella to the falls was 4,000 rupee, they all say 6,000 only but you can definitely find someone who will do it for 4,000 just takes a bit of bartering and searching !

The Diyaluma Falls were such a beautiful sight as it had rained and water was gushing. This water fall is the second highest water fall in Sri-Lanka and the 361 st highest waterfall in the world. It is an amazing sight during the  rainy season. It is worthwhile seeing and it is easy to see, it as it is by the road side.

You can watch the lower and the highest cascade of Diyaluma Falls on the Wellawaya Road. That is called Lower Diyaluma Falls. But the real treasure is the Upper Diyaluma Falls, for which you have to hike up through the jungle. It has multiple cascades and natural pools of every size, each one unique in its own way. You can reach the top of the falls in a considerably short time. There are small shops set up at some places as well. Please make sure to bring back the polythene and plastic you take. Leave only your footprints.

Stunning multiple waterfalls and a great place to swim. "Guides" are not needed !! After thoroughly researching the falls we were confident on how to get to them with clear instructions saved on our phones. after parking our Tuk tuk at the top carpark we were asked multiple times if we would like a guide. After saying no and following our saved directions we set off to find our path only to be followed by one of the "guides" from the carpark. We were told we were going the wrong way and he directed us down some path in which he said was the right way. We trusted this advice as we thought he was being genuinely helpful. This path was overgrown and full of leeches (have a bottle of insect repellent and lighter ready to spray/burn them off as soon as you feel them) after eventually reaching and exploring the waterfalls we found a much much better path back. we popped out (surprise, surprise) where we were originally headed before being led astray by the guides advice. After returning to our Tuk Tuk and confronting the guide we asked him if the path we were going to follow was were the guides go and he laughed in our face and said yes. We expressed our disappointment at his actions and said in Australia or New zealand we would never do this to tourists or deliberately lead them astray simply because they chose to make their own way. Below are clear instructions how to get the falls without utilising the guides who take advantage of tourists and deliberately confuse them or make up that google maps wont work or that its extremely difficult to find the falls, both of which turned out to be lies. Follow this reviews instructions - however after walking past the green and white gate walk for about 50m then take a sharp right onto a wide path. From there traverse around the hillside towards the sound of rushing water and you'll find the various waterfalls.

There are two ways to see this beautiful waterfall: from below - you need to overcome big high stones (of you need to wear snickers, better to have snickers for tracking), and then you‚Äôll enjoy a very cool view of the waterfall from the earth, it‚Äôs very high and athmospheric, the sun and drops when you are inside the waterfall are amazing! And the second way - upper view, and it‚Äôs absolutely unbelievable , because upstairs you have a possibility to visit all small and so small ponds connected with each other! And you can also swim inside them and enjoy a very amazing Mountain View from the very high spots. It‚Äôs one of the most beautiful waterfalls we‚Äôve ever seen at the moment. Less people. And very cool route, cause you need to go through the jungle. Absolutely must visit. Much better and more beautiful than Rawana waterfall.

We have visited the fall today. We had to hike to the upper coarse of the fall to swim. We are not sure how to go up and we hire a guide to walk up. We walk up from Diyaluma Inn. There are plenty of Leeches en route. We feel very uncomfortable being bite by the leeches. The hike is medium level~ and have to go up the rocky road. We have chatted with other tourist and find out there is another route to leave the fall. The route is better and no leeches.

Upper diyaluma is a place with a beautiful view. If you planning to camp in upper diyaluma , first go to koslanda and from there go to poonagla which is about 7km. There are few other routs too to go to upper diyaluma but from poonagala it‚Äôs shorter and there are places to park your vehicles safe too. You can hire a person from poonagala for directions to the falls or you can even follow others. From there it‚Äôs about 45 minutes walk and it‚Äôs not a difficult walk. There are places to do camping and on a holiday or weekend there will be many people camping. So if you planning on a holiday, make sure you reach the place as early as possible so you can get a good place to pitch your tents. Also there is a small shop where you can get roti and some curries. It‚Äôs not a fixed shop so timings of the shop changes depending on the crowed. If you can get hold of the old but nice person who is at the shop you don‚Äôt need to worry about your food. Please minimize your plastic use while your are there and make sure you don‚Äôt leave any plastic behind.
That is a vest waterfall hikking expirience at the koslanda area with 2nd highest waterfall in sri lanka.

Diyaluma waterfall üì∏‚òù Beautiful natural place. Those who wants to feel the real nature this is the place.You can swim in the pools and even jump off cliffs. Beautiful views! #nice #enjoy #srylankanadventures #nature_water #nature_swim_pool üèä #like #travelwiththiraj We went to this place üöó Enjoying my client oscar & his wife rosüíë

What a remarkable place in Sri Lanka. It‚Äôs just wow. Stunning waterfall. You will find a very relaxing surrounding area there as well. No words to tell about this destination and this beautiful, natural waterfall. Sri Lankans are surely one of those lucky people on Earth.

We are a family of 4 (2 kids age 10/13) and spent the day around the falls. We took a bus from Ella to Wellawaya (45 min, 300 rs). From there, our guide for the day (Tharindu, +94 719702456) picked us up by tuktuk. Of you have a car, you could also come straight to the falls on your own. Tharindu lives at the base of the falls. We first spent half and hour climbing and playing on the boulders at the bottom of the falls/river. Then Tharindu brought us with the tuktuk halfway up the mountain, from where we hiked 30 min to the falls. We recommend bringing a guide, because it saves you a lot of walking and you won‚Äôt get lost (which is easy). When we got to the top of the falls, it was a bit crowded with locals because of the weekend. We hiked 10 min further up to Upper Diyaluma falls, which where even nicer! There, we swam in the pools and climbed up to the top, from where our kids jumped off from a 8 meter rock in the pool! Awesome! Tharindu was really nice and helpful and encouraged the kids with the swimming and jumping. He also makes really nice pictures (and loves the panorama setting!). We had a great day all together. Don‚Äôt hesitate to give Tharindu a call.
Waterfall of about 100 meters high. It's possible to go in the pool, buy only if the water level is not too high.

Amazing and dreamy waterfall with a slippery hill. Worth to bring good shoes and clothes but great for a jump in the waterfall and the natural slide. A lot of locals offering tours. Very nice people but not necessarily needed.

A must do when visiting Sri Lanka. There's a place in Naulla where you can drive up and park the vehicles. From there you can hike up for about 1.5km We had a superb guide called Shan. He can be contacted on +94711635697 He knows all the spots to take breathtaking photos and have a dip in the ice cold water gushing from the rocks.

Impressive waterfall, with a good view from the roadside bridge. There is a walk you can do to the top of it, but it looks like hot work so we didn't bother. About a 20 minute detour off of the main road up to Ella, which we thought was worth it.

My husband and I hiked the Diyaluma Falls, we hired a guide with a tuktuk, we ride the tuktuk for like 7 minutes, then we contined by foot. the views from the top are great, we enjoyed the pools so much. make sure you wear the right shoes for this hike, as it is not an easy one. our great guide was with us the whole time, his name is Tharindu Mihiranga, his phone number: +94719702456.

Contact of a guide while visiting Dialuma falls. He lives on the path to the falls and seemed like knowing the area quite well. We paid 1000 rupees for a few hours of trekking. To go there, we got out of the bus (from Wellawaya to Haputale) very close to Naulla where there is a sign saying ‚ÄòShortcut to Dialuma‚Äô. Just follow the path and you will see his house in a few hundred meters. Name is Dinesh and number 071 0625851 and 071 9881825.

If u traveling in ella and Haputhale Diyaluma is best place to visit . U can get there easily from bottom of diyaluma falls when u walking down to koslanda direction around the 300m , there is foot path to top that will take a 30min to reach

Definetly worth the hike and worth the adrenaline rush when you swim in the pools up top! Don't forget to take the diyaluma short cut trail as it makes the access to the top much easier ! If you can go early in the morning that would be great as it gets busier as the day passes

We got a guide, but you don't absolutely need one. We didn't regret having a guide because we are quite weak, and at least the guide could.help us at some part. Once you reach the top, there's many "pools". There's quite some people, but it's not overly crowded. If the big "pool" is crowded, just head to behind and there are small pool with small falls. Stand under the fall and let it wash away all your tiredness. It's about 1 hr past drive from ella town, but I highly recommend it. As compared to ravana falls (we went past twice), diyaluma looks alot better!
I suggest you to roam around Nuwara Eli, Haputale and then at last come to see the Diyaluma falls.. go under the water dropping and throw away your tiredness!! No words to explain that feeling!!!

We've spent almost 3 weeks in sri lankan and this was by far the best thing. We got a tuk tuk from Ella for 5000 rupee for 3 people. The guy also guided us on foot to the actual falls (you won't find them on your own). It is amazing. The waterfall isnt touristy at all so the path is overgrown so you'll  need to watch out for leeches and ticks. Despite this it's so worth it. Don't forget your swimmers as there is lots of jumping and swimming to be had. Enjoy!

Diyaluma Falls is the second highest waterfall in Sri Lanka at 720ft high. Located about 6km from Koslanda in the Badulla District, and 38km from Ella, this horsetail waterfall has multiple falls and natural pools for you to dive into, refresh yourself and explore. Diyaluma Falls can be explored from both above and below, as the base of the falls also has a pool you can dive into! The best time to visit would be for sunrise as you get to see the rising sun shine upon the waves crashing down, however, sunset isn‚Äôt a bad option either, just be weary that you may need to travel back towards the main road in total darkness.

It was fascinating waterfall. We had a hard time to go up , i had an injury on the way. But the view the spot was amazing. One of the most beautiful place in my life i see. But coz alot of things happen to us we perefer to come down as soon as we can. My friend fell into the lake , i sliped on the rocks. We didnt take any first aid with ourself. If i go back before i go to this place i really pack some first aid with my self and then go to this beautiful place.

Thia waterfall is amazing ! First, the hike to the uppermost level of the waterfall takes you through breathtaking scenery. Mind that you have to do proper research online so you find out the right way for the beautiful hike. The starting point is a fee hundred meters South from Diyaluma Falls Inn. The local tuk tuk drivers will try to sell you tours, no need to get one. Once you get to the top of the waterfall, you start to descend, following the flow of water and you go through several ‚Äústages‚Äù of the waterfall, each with beautiful little pools where you can take baths. The lowest level is actually the top of the waterfall that you see from the main road. From there, you descend on a dirt path and reach a point close to Naulla village. So, the start and end points are different. This is the best way to go, in my opinion. You will enjoy amazing views and a good workout ;)

There is quite a bumpy road to get to these falls on the A4. They were worth it though even though there is not much water coming down. We didn‚Äôt try to get to the top of the falls but our driver said it was possible.

We didnt go up top which we really should have but we still really enjoyed the view from below. You can climb to the base and actually swim in the water fall while letting the water fall on you. Really beautiful place but really far from everything.

I gave it 4 stars because of the tough climb to get to the top. Otherwise, it is indeed a multi-level beautiful waterfall with a number of pools to sit or have fun in. We rode a motorbike from Ella, took about 1-1.5hrs. Fairly good roads  except for the last 15min stretch which were bumpier. At the base of the waterfall (some distance away from the actual waterfall), there is a small parking area and an inn. There are a few local boys/ young men waiting and will offer their service as a guide. We could have bargained to 1500lkr but paid the 2000lkr asked, after hearing from other travellers at our guesthouse how they topped up 500lkr in the end after experiencing the amount of walking and the guide waiting to bring them down at the end. The walk up starts with a fairly straightforward dirt path through rubber trees and a small cluster of houses. However, the rest of it is a climb up the mountain, on uneven, scrabbly rocks, large and small, and cut-in steps in the ground. You should be young or of moderate fitness to do this. Definitely wear proper shoes and have sunscreen and water. Preferably start early in the day and wear longer pants, as the tall grass growing towards the path for much of the climb can get itchy after a while. You will also appreciate the helping hand of the guide as you climb.. At the top there is a coconut seller, then slightly downhill to the actual waterfall. It is fairly easy to get to the various levels of the waterfall. Be careful stepping in and out of the pools as the rocks are slippery with moss. There is only a roti and coconut seller at the waterfall itself. Bring some snacks or you can buy them from the few village grocery shops on the road in. Very friendly locals, we smiled and waved to everyone. From the bottom of the waterfall, you will need to climb back up again to the top where the coconut seller is, to go all the way down again. It takes about 1hr each way.

This place is behind a hike. The hike up the hill tries to kill you but when you get to natures own pools.. It is just worth it. The scenery and atmosphere is something out of this world, so beautiful. There is many pools to hang out in and we definetly recommend to start your cooling down process from the bottom pools and to work your way up the hill. We were lucky to have our Tuktuk driver as a guide, you should really hire someone to get the most out of this place!!

This place is really amazing, maybe one of the best place to visit in Sri Lanka, you can go to the top of the fall, swim and have some great picture, it's good to go with a local guide, because you need to walk in jungle for around 2Km, and it's difficult to find the way...

Lower Diyaluma falls can be seen from the roadside - a massive cascade. But the real treasure are upper Diyaluma falls, a 3/4 mile hike up. There are multiple accessible bathing waterfall pools  - each one unique. Most are easy to enter pools but one is for daredevils only -  a 5m deep pool with a 20m high edge to jump from!

Beautiful waterfall. You can swim at the top so wear swimming gear. Do this with a guide as you‚Äôll probably get lost otherwise. We paid 1500 LKR for ours with a group of 3. Don‚Äôt believe the tuk tuk drovers who threaten you with a ‚Äú3 hour walk‚Äù to the top - with moderate fitness you can do it in about an hour going at a comfortable pace. Tuk tuk doesn‚Äôt get you anywhere near the top and you still have the hardest part of the walk to do so don‚Äôt waste your money.

My wife and I (both 27) hired a scooter from Ella and drove down to Diyaluma and Buduruwagala. It was an incredible day and Diyaluma is like nothing else in the world. The drive from Ella was stunning as we drove through the mountains and then the fields. We went to Diyaluma first as it is more weather dependent and easier to climb in the morning before the heat. We parked up at the bottom of the falls and paid a local 1000 rupees to take us to the top (we probably could have haggled them down lower). Only pay them to take you up, as once you know the way it's easy to follow it back down. No need to pay them to wait! At the top there are a succession of waterfalls and pools which you can swim in and take photos of. It is very peaceful and beautiful and very few other people were there. We worked our way down the falls until we came to the final 170m fall. It is absolutely breathtaking and feels like you are standing at the top of the world looking down on it. The vertical drop means the view is completely unobscured. We This is an amazing place and is our top recommendation for everyone visiting the hill country. Make the effort to visit from Ella and you will be rewarded.

The waterfalls were lovely and definitely worth a visit however you may want to get a guide. It seems compared to other reviews we went the hard way as ours was about a hour hike or more up rocks with a steep incline. I am quite fit but it was not easy. Definitely doable but will leave you breathless. Also there are leeches in the water so bear this in mind. If you go in the pools with running water you should be ok but check yourself before you leave. This is a whole day trek so I would leave early I wouldn't want to be walking around in the dark. You can catch a bus there first to Wyallaway then another bus to the falls very cheap compared to a tuk tuk.

As you have likely read, this is the second highest waterfall in Sri Lanka. Whether that‚Äôs the main falls, or the combination of all three in the system, I couldn‚Äôt figure out. That however didn‚Äôt distract from the breathtaking beauty of the falls and the surrounding area. We caught a Tuk Tuk from Ella, which is probably the best option. It took roughly 1.5 hours to get to the base of the falls, and gave us the opportunity to enjoy the surrounding countryside. If driving from Ella, you‚Äôll get to see Little Adam‚Äôs Peak, Ella Rock and can stop at Ravena falls on the way. From the base, you can ether walk, or take a Tuk Tuk (over some incredibly rocky ground - find an experienced driver!) half way, and walk the remaining kilometer. At the peak, you‚Äôll find a smaller falls, which runs through pools into the main attraction. The water was clear, warm and a great reward after the hike. The view from the top is also one of the best we‚Äôve found so far. The walk is a little steep but should be suitable for most. Bring some snacks and make sure to include this in your itenerary if you have the time!

This beautiful water fall is only the second heighst, next to Bambarakanda falls.you need to walk a long way to observe many falls but this unique water fall is by the side of Colombo-Baticaloa main road and there are many access to it. I too the Haputale Beragal road where you turn from Beragal to reach the fall and it takes about 45 minutes. On rainy days the flow of the fall changes rapidly , therefore it is a bit dangerous to bath in it. As the spray falls right to the road you have to be careful with your camera lenses. However it is a beautiful and a panoramic site to watch the white water falling . When the weather is dry and the rate of water falling is less, it would be good to have a dip but when it rains and the water fall changes its falling rate, better not take undue risks in bathing as the flow of water suddenly increase from the top.
Diyaluma falls is a must visit and its more better if u can camp up there or below the stream. Sunsets are magical from uptop
Start ur hike  early morning to avoid traffic on the hiking route and less photo bombing  by others and it's less warm. Takes about 40mins ~ 1hr one way

This is one of the hidden gem of a waterfall in Sri Lanka. Bandarawela, via poonagala estate can go to this place. After half an hour trek. Wild elephants are there so better to be cautious. There are three steps of the waterfall. Can go to each and everyone of them. Can have a bath but better to keep an eye of flash floods. On the last step there is a steep drop so better to watch out when having a bath there. Truly wonderful experience and hidden treasure of nature.

It's quite the sight to take in . There is a hidden path on to the left of the waterfall which can be used to get close to the base of the fall. Tread carefully along this side and you will be rewarded for your attempt. There is also a way to reach the top of the falls. Speak to the locals and they will tell you the best way to the top. Enjoy Diyaluma !
Alongside the road you cross one of the most spectacular waterfalls in Sri Lanka and you can get ou of your car or tuktuk to make the most beautiful photographs

Away from Badulla-colombo main road, at the Beragala junction , theres a road that leads to the falls. Diyaluma falls is situated near the main road,you can have a rest before you pass it. Really worth watching. Such an amazing falls.
Another lovely waterfall in the hills of Sri Lanka. You can see it from the road and viewing platform. Worth a short break when passing.
We have gone here a couple of times and each time it is just as magical as first time! Can get a bit busy during peak season so go early and spend an hour there immersing in the beauty.

We were dropped off the Poonagala road where the upper Diyaluma falls trek started. At first we didn‚Äôt knew which way to go, but that‚Äôs not a problem. There is always someone who will guide you to the waterfall. At first, we tried the find the location on our own. After a while, we decided to pay a guide, which was a very good decision as it was fast and cheap. Finally we arrived at the top of the diyaluma falls, but it was not what I expected. So many people in the pools and so touristic. Not an instagram worthy picture.. but the view was amazing!! Watch out when you go to visit the diyaluma falls when it rains, it‚Äôs sooo slippery!!

Diyaluma falls is a beautiful water fall, it was a nice sight as it was after the rains. Saw it after a very long time, & the good thing is there is a new enclosed area to watch the falls & take photographs as people had to see it from the main road which is very dangerous. Thanks to whoever did it.
amazing hike and views are great at the top- foolishly forgot to bring our stuff for a swim which was a shame as loads of great pools for dip

it's about an easy 30 minute trail path walk from the car park. directions: Facing the car park take the road left and follow it bearing right around the corner. After about 5 minutes you will come across and green and white gate (looks like private property drive going downhill). Go through the gate, or if it's locked you can walk around it. a few metres in front is a sign and take the path that leads right. it's a clear footpath the whole way and it leads through a field of long grass, not very steep. follow this trail for about 15/20 minutes and you will hear the waterfall. you will see a hut and follow the path to the right a few hundred metres. you will see the pools and the rest is pretty simple from there! Be careful the big rock you have to walk across is quite steep, some people were sliding down on their bums. its totally worth it even just to swim around the upper pools, they are beautiful. some points you can jump off ledges into, they're very deep. the Sri Lankan children are dare devils and very fun to watch. we didn't go down to the actual waterfall because we didn't have time, our taxi driver gave us 2 hours. but could have easily spent half a day here.

It's right at the side of the main road. So if you are coming this way you can stop and admire it. I would not drive out of the way for hours for this one. But if you are going that way definitely have a look.

Natural rock pools and waterfalls. We first visited the bottom of the falls by tuk tuk, then he drove us another 30 minutes to reach a property at the top. From here we walked about 20-30 minutes with the help of our tuk tuk driver pointing us in the right direction. People will ask to take you on a ‚Äòguided‚Äô tour, our driver said not to do this because it‚Äôs unsafe and costs a lot of money. The people offering tours are not guides and not have licenses. You have to pay 100 rupee parking fee at the place you park your tuk tuk or scooter. After the walk we then reached the first rock pool and waterfall where you can bathe and jump down a big waterfall into a plunge pool. You can then ask some locals to direct you to a path that takes you to the edge of where the waterfall drops down 200 or so metres. Moderate fitness level recommended.

It is situated 6-10 km away from Koslanda in Badulla District on Colombo-Badulla highway.The foot of the Diyaluma falls is quite easy to reach within an hour by tuk-tuk, car or motorbike. The last 15 minutes of the drive will be uphill and the road isn‚Äôt the best from that point. At the foot of the waterfall, pass the bridge and follow the path to the waterfall. Beautiful surrounding. Very risky to bath here during rainy days. Near to waterfall you can have hot plain tea with juggery.

Such a beautiful waterfall and it‚Äôs worth climbing to the top so you can play and swim in the natural pools and then walk alongside the falls to the point where it drops. It‚Äôs really good fun! We found a local kid who was offering to take us and we joined up with another couple of people and it cost us 1,500rupees between us 4- worth it to get the local perspective, walking through rubber tree factories and beautiful scenery. Be prepared for a good 20min hike uphill so wear trainers for better grip. The locals do it in flit flips no issue but us Westerners aren‚Äôt used to this terrain.
On our way to Koslanda we saw this beautiful waterfall. It is worth stopping by. The road on the highland of Sri Lanka is beautiful in general.

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. It took us one hour and a half to drive from Liptons Seat to these waterfalls... Impressive in heighth, but unfortunately not too much water coming down outside the monsoon season. We did not have the time to walk to the top to take a swim.
We stopped in Koslanda and followed a local guide to the top of the waterfall. We swam in a pool (which we had all to ourselves) and continued the climb down. It was beautiful and well worth it.
We stop by, went for a walk and a short dip inn the bottom pool. We ended up talking to people from all over the world.

We drove here by motorbike from Ella and it took a us about 1.5 hours with photo breaks etc. There wasn‚Äôt a lot of water despite visiting in rainy season but because it was so windy, it produced some awesome shapes with the water. If you have time and transport, I‚Äôd deffo recommend a visit as it‚Äôs the 2nd tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka.

We went to this waterfall in July 2018. To get to the top of the waterfall, you can go alone or ask a guide to take you there. You can find those guides at the bridge. We had a really awesome guide, called Sudu. You can ask after him when you're there, he's awesome and he will give a lot of extra information on the way to the top. During the hike, there's even a chance that you will spot some elephants when you're in luck. One of the best experiences of my life!

We hired a scooter in Ella and made our way out here during our day. We wished we had been better prepared time wise and been able to go to the top of the falls but it was still awesome from the bottom. We went for a swim under the waterfall and it was a pretty cool experience I‚Äôd recommend to check it out. Took us about an hour via scooter from Ella.

We hired a scooter in Ella and stopped off at Diyaluma Falls on a bit of a round trip in the countryside. The road to get there was in good condition and picturesque. The Diyaluma Falls are easily seen from the road which makes it easy for pulling over and having a look.

It is a long drive along a terrible road to get to here, which is why you don't get many foreign tourists. I saw coach loads of Sri Lankans, though. Not really worth walking up the track to the foot of the waterfall -- you get a better view from the road, especially about 500m toward Wellawaya. It is rather puny if there has been no rain, but after a decent rainstorm it is stunning.

It's the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka but so what?  You can only view it from the busy road that goes by it. Its far too dangerous to try and even get your toes in the water or wash your face. There is no safe access to the water either
At 171m, Petaluma Ella fall is the third highest waterfall in Sri lanka, it is natural swimming pool here,

beautiful falls, next to the road. So you don't need to hike there. It is a bit of a D-tour to get here, as the road to/from the falls is not in good shape. We could only drive like 40 km/h the whole way. But it is worth it!
We weren't expecting the falls to be so dramatically beautiful.  We also enjoyed seeing the macaques in this area.

We returned here after a year away and the falls were not so spectacular as we have seen on previous occasions, but we were not in the heavy rainy season. At all times of year these falls are impressive being some 220m in height. They are very easily accessible on the highway from Belihul Oya to Wellawaya and one can easily park, enjoy a splash in the water and take advantage of the road-side vendors who sell water, corn, nibbles and so on. As with all falls, the rainy period is by far the best time to see them at their spectacular best.

We took the bus from Haputale and asked the driver to drop us at the Diyaluma waterfall (LKR 80 / $0.50). Its a very beautiful waterfall, if you can make time for it, don't miss it. Its worth it, no entrance fees. It rained two days in a row before we came to the falls and we got a very good view. You can see it from the main road and even feel the mist while standing on the road. There are local shops where you can get a corn or mango or some other local fruit. We went back on a bus, there is a bus every hour and half.
A nice waterfall where you can take a dip.  Easy to get to and cool.  Can get quite busy mid morning so get there early.  Not sure how high you can climb, but a couple of hidden gems

This is the second highest waterfall in Sri Lanka at 220 metres but we learnt that it is far more spectacular in the wet season and when you can soaked standing on the road next to the waterfall. Local vendors sell freshly cooked corn on the cob .

A beautiful water fall along the Koslanda- Beragala - Wellawaya road, lovely for photographs. One can see it from the road without going up to the waterfall. Unfortunately it was not at its full beauty due to the drought. During the rainy season it is such a beautiful sight. One of the nicest water falls in Sri-Lanka.
this is probably the third time i visited the waterfall and never saw so much of water before and it's awesome..

So everyone can enjoy the beauty of Diyaluma easily by the Koslanda - Wellawaya road. There is a way to get to the top of Diyaluma with a short and enjoyable hike. You have to travel  bit further towards Poonagala and find the foot path by the makaldeniya bend. On the way to Poonagala also you will find several beautiful rivers. Ask a local they will show you the road. Then there is a hike to go to the top of Diyaluma. Go to there around 9-9:30 in the morning because a local warned me that there are elephants around 6-7 in the morning. At the end of the hike, you can get down to the point where the water finally descends the 200m. You can peep over the edge the look down at the main road. Be care full. The pool created by the first cascade is good for bath. The view over the edge is amazing and worth all the steps in the hike. See the pictures.

Although we came from the other direction and it took 45 minutes each way, the falls were well worth the trip, even the hold-up on the way back as they were renovating a large bridge!  The falls are 220 metres high and tumble in long silvery plumes against a dark brown rock-face. There are also small refreshment places nearby.  You may do a bit of rock scrambling to get close if you wish, but the best view is from the road bridge. Of all the falls that we saw in Sri Lanka, this was probably the best.

DIyaluma waterfall is one of the tallest once in Sri Lanka. This is few of waterfalls that can be access easily by a vehicle including public transport as this has situated next to a main road. For a good view, you have to go in rainy season as in dry season very little water will fall.

Diyaluma Falls is the second highest water fall in Sri lanka, this water fall is located between Koslanda - Wellawaya road. We stay at Haputale and went for a excursion to visit Diyaluma Falls. Beautiful place to visit.
Situated at the roadside of Haputale to Wellavaya road. There is a observation platform to watch built in the period of previous government.

The Diyaluma Falls can be seen from afar as you approach them travelling from Wellawaya to Beragala. We have seen these falls on many occasions but strongly advise, if possible, to visit during the wet season when they are spectacular. On this occasion (January) we remained impressed by the incredible height of the falls but the volume of water was very low. There are places to get water, drinks and snacks on the roadside at the foot of the falls. If travelling this road, it is worth stopping to enjoy the incredible power of nature.

You must see this place in rainy season .November,December or April  the waterfall is full of water.Diyaluma is near by the Wallawaya Beragala  road  you have to climb  some places to see the nice view carefully

On the way to Tissamaharama from Ella we took a slight detour (12 Kms, I believe) on a bumpy road and arrived at this gem. Despite it being a dry season and the flow of water anything but incredible, the tall waterfall was a nice sight. There were hardly any tourists. One can easily spend a good 30 minutes over here. Highly recommended during the wet season.

after going to Rawana falls and sharing the beauty with 40-50 other backpackers, heading to Ella where we were the only people around was such a treat.  We didn't hike up to the top but jumped into the water where recent rains had the waterfalls coming down heavily.  It takes about 5-10 minutes to trek up the rocks and make sure you bring shoes not flip flops.
It was a rainy day but at the verge of drought .so current of water was there but enough to satisfy us.tried to climb Ella .but late day, rain and wild elephant prevented the journey

The majestic Diyaluma Falls drops 220 metres and is best seen during the rainy season when there is a lot of water flowing. It has been called the "waterfall of smoking water." It is on the Beragala to Wellawaya road, a short distance from the small town of Koslanda. The road is narrow, potholed and has some mud, so be careful when driving or riding, especially in wet weather.
Very beautiful waterfall.... close to Koslanda.. You can visit on your way to Beragala from Wellawaya.
This is just next to the main road from Beragala to Wellawaya. Can easily reach by public transportation. For adventure seekers, there is a path to climb to the top of the falls.

We visited here on the advice of our guesthouse in Haputale. We hiked up and down Lipton's Seat in the morning and then caught the Wellawaya bus at about 2pm. Bus was mega full (it was a Sunday) and we didn't get a seat. It was hot and bumpy and we were happy to get of the bus after 1hr and a half. It was dry season so there wasn't much water, but the falls were impressive nonetheless. We didn't hang around too long at the bottom because it was a bit touristy. Instead we attempted the hike to the top, as described in the Lonely Planet (2012 edition). A young boy from the village volunteered to guide us along the way. To be honest we would have struggled without him, so we gave him 10Rs. ostensibly to buy school supplies. He put us on the right path and we scrambled up for 20min to the top. You should make sure to take plenty of water for the hike, and don't wear flip-flops. At the top we hoped to have the pools to ourselves, as we were hot and sweaty and just wanted to jump in the water. Surprisingly there were a few groups of locals (one getting a bit boozy), and some German girls attracting attention in their bikinis. We just took our boots off and cooled our feet off while chatting to the locals (apparently a family of wild elephants come here for a drink most days at around 6:30pm). Sadly we didn't go to the top of the actual falls, because we had to get the bus back to Haputale. It looked really cool and would probably make a great photo. The REAL HIGHLIGHT for me was in fact the bus ride back up to Haputale. Buses going up come approx. every 30min, and the last one is at 1830. It took us just over an hour to hike up, 20min at the top, and 45min to get back down, so we caught the bus at about 1720. There was plenty of space on the bus, and it was a magical journey through the forested hills overlooking the southern lowlands as the sun sets over the mountains. Keep your eyes peeled for macaques as you drive up! Give yourself more time than we did if you're using public transport. Alternatively, if you have your own transport, take a torch with you, stay to see the elephants. :)
A beautiful sight to behold. You could actually take a bath at the foot of the falls. Great photography opportunity.

It is great to watch the waterfalls by the koslanda-wellawaya road, sipping tea seated in a road side shop. But there is a way to get to the top of the fall. One has to travel bit further towards poonagala and find the foot path by the makaldeniya bend. Ask a local they will show you the path. After some tough terrain one can get to the place where the cascade begins. The cascade consists about 7 levels before reaching the 200 meter odd diyaluma fall. You can make your way through the through the tall manna to the lower levels. Mind your steps! The are cases of accidental and suicidal death caused by falling over one of the cascade. Extremely slippery. Stay off the edges. The pool created by the first cascade is good for bath. You can get down to the point where the water finally descends the 200m. You can peep over the edge the look down at the main road. Be care full. Great for a short hike. I made this trip alone. But if you can find a companion. Never know when things can go wrong.
Another beautiful waterfall in the country and a great place for amazing photograph. The visit to this place so much worth ...
Beautiful waterfall close to where we stayed - Living Heritage, Koslanda - we stopped to enjoy the scenery and take some photos on our way.

This is by far one of the best waterfalls I've been to. The main reasons for that is , there are less people frequenting this place (not a soul was around when we were there) and entire experience from the trek to having a dip in a natural pool at the very top of Sri Lankan's second highest waterfall was epic! The route to this place is long and there's a 45-60mins trek to get to the spot. If your going here for the first time get some local to guide you.

Five kilometres east of Koslanda the road passes the 171m-high Diyaluma Falls, Sri Lanka‚Äôs third-highest waterfall. Cascading down an escarpment of the Koslanda Plateau, the stream is fairly small, but it quickly escalates after a downpour. The falls leap over a cliff face and fall in one clear drop to a pool below.

Traveling between Koslanda and Weliwaya on the small and narrow but scenic A4 stretch will bring you face to face with the beautiful Diyaluma Falls.  dropping from a massive cliff.  Definitely worth stopping and getting your way here to check it out.
Fine to drive by but not worth a major diversion. In these hills there are many arresting views and this is but one. We stopped for five mins and on we went...

Again a SL attraction that I personally do not find particularly attractive. Yes, nice waterfall. But the approach is difficult. No stairs, lots of floating garbage and pesky vendors that try to peddle their stuff. I don't buy stuff out of principle, so they tried the coin scam on me. His daughter was collecting coins and only the 2 Euro coin was missing.
Could watch the falling water for ages. Unfortunately waterfalls are next to the road and there is not much place to sit, relax and see time pass by.
They are down a narrow bumpy road,  but worth the trip. We visited them on our way from Horton Plains to Udawalawe. Well worth  a visit.

In September when I visited the waterfall, the stream was fairly small.  Probably, at the end of the rain season the falls will  be more spectacular.  It is a short walk from the road, about 200 meters.  The path and steps to the waterfall are in excellent condition. It is not the most impressive waterfall I've  seen, but worth a visit.  So if you are passing by, go and have a look.  Entrance price =150 LKR.

Roadside falls that are a welcome relief in the heat. If you are brave enough you can have a little dance in the spray or a wash but just standing at the viewing platform is as good as anything. Easy to get to from welawaya or koslanda on the A4 but take some time to find a car service who can take you to the top as there is a fabulous walk along the hill tops. Beautiful waterfall that will brighten your day and make you smile
Height 220m. Second Highest waterfall in sri lanka. Located in dry zone. A4 road between Koslanda and wellawaya (205-206)km

I have heard about this waterfalls, but was under the impression that this was even smaller than Dunhinda. So I was not interested in visiting this before. Last week I went there with my wife, and was surprised seeing the beauty of it. It is reasonable that people saying that this is the most beautiful waterfalls in Sri Lanka; but unfortunately there are no Cameras that could capture the real beauty of it with the wind and the mist with the real feeling when you be there for real. If you do not see any specialty when you just watch its photographs, I would recommend you to visit the place and experience it with your own eyes. I guarantee that you would agree with me then.
One of the most beautiful waterfalls in Sri-Lanka, its really nice during the rainy season, but even in the drought water trickles by. Well worth a visit.

This is a nice waterfall in between Koslanda and Wellawaya, by the side of an undulated road. Access to this place is not convenient and not worth unless passing the area on your way to some other place.

What a amazing place in Sri lanka... wooowwww....  very nice waterfall. And also very calm surrounded area. No words to say about this place and this natural waterfall. Sri Lankans are very lucky to had this waterfall. I love  it....
Beautifull waterfall, very good distance from Kandy and nice walk. The view is fantastic en great, nature of Sri Lanka is superb!
Okay this place was free with an amazing up close view of the falls. If you are in shape you can climb to get closer to the falls and bathe.... Great pictures and yes some monkeys...

We passed this waterfall at the end of the mansoon period and because of the rain more water thundered down as usual. Because of the height and the wind the water falls everytime in a different direction downwards. Enjoy the few with a nice lunch or just a drink at the closeby Diyaluma Falls Inn

We made a detour from Wellawaya in our rental car and were not disappointed. The waterfall is beautiful! It's a quiet place, so you can enjoy a picknick without being bothered by local people or crowds of touristst. On this topic we read other comments of other people who made a walk to the top of the falls. When you have time, try it. The waterfalles are on the edge of the escparment and the views into the lowlands must be great.

The Diyaluma falls are well worth seeing in all seasons but are incredibly powerful and dramatic after seasonal rains. The local environment is very beautiful and it is wonderful to watch the water crashing down on to the rocks with a backcloth of trees and mountains. A bridge at the foot of the falls is a very popular tourist stopping place and there are several places within walking distance to purchase drinks and snacks.

This is a really a marvel of mother nature . Great view .Jungle behind the waterfall .It is about 10 minutes walk from Diyaluma falls inn. love the climate .sensational climate.Had a wonderful time over there

I have passed by this water fall many times & am sad to see it at this state as it is approx 10% of what it used to be. The food / tea kiosk at the bridge are far from clean. We managed to patronize a restaurant approx 400 meters down the road towards Wellawaya which had a clean toilet & offered decent food.

The picture shown is definitely not of Diyaluma. I am having my adventure treks to this place more that 10 times a year, and therefore can vouch for the inaccuracy. TASK ADVENTURE organizes treks to upper diyaluma with or without an abseiling point before the exact point that the fall is shooting its water cannon to the ground which is 628 feet below. An adrenaline pumping view. With TASK ADVENTURE the safety is not an issue as they are equipped with everything needed.
Very beautiful waterfall that will make you go wow specially during the rainy season. Truly a marvel of mother nature. Good place to have a bath as well
Even in the dry season, when we were there, these falls are very special.  The drop is 220 meters   and when the falls reach the road, they flow in many directions over large boulders.

The waterfall offers really great views both from the bottom and the top. It's not an easy walk but it is worth it, especialy because you can take an awesome bath in the pools at the top. Definitely recommend it!
Good fun to climb to the top pool where you can take a dip with the locals. Its a bit of a scramble to the top but its worth it.
We were passing and stopped for a bit. Glad we didn't make a special effort. Bandarakwela falls was much better.

i and my family had a thoroughly enjoyable trip to this 170 m high waterfall . it is about 14 km from the hilly town of Haputale. The view moving out of the this town is captivating as it is situated on a ridge .  the bus trip from Haputale to the Diyaluma falls takes 45 minutes., going towards welawaya. The falls is  situated by the roadside with sprays falling onto the road . we took a walk thru the rubber plantation with many village homes enroute. there is a few paths leading up but one can always ask the village folks.  A young boy of 12 years became our guide and he is really well informed and fun to be with. we walked up  through temperate shrub land for about 45 minutes with many stops along the way to enjoy the views . At  the top it was pristine and gives a top of the world feeling looking down at the massive falls below.  many small falls are scattered around and provided much fun for my teenage childrem.  One can choose to explore further inland following the river but it was too tiring. there are  villagers selling coconuts and food  at the bottom of the falls.

This beautiful waterfall is just by the side of the road and is Sri Lanka's third highest waterfall.  The waterfall was full of water when we went and there was a spray of mist as you walk past !  Although the drive from beragala to diyaluma was lovely , the road surface was rutty making it a bumpy ride !

Second tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka. If you like to be more adventurous, try the Poonagala -Koslanda route from Bandarawela to see this waterfall Its a more scenic route through the tea estates. Recommend a four-wheel vehicle if you decide on this route.
It was not in full force when we passed everytime we returned to the Living Heritage hotel.  But still very beautiful.

We went to the Diyaluma falls to stay at the Inn next to the falls after seeing the beautiful pictures on the website. The views here are absolutely stunning. However after taking a look around the Inn we were so put off even the views werent enough to make us stay at the Diyaluma Falls Inn. The proprietor has to seriously consider  a makeover of the place to have any one stay there. The toilets are dripping and dirty and the rooms are dingy and musty. It was a real pity to see the place as the location is absolutely brilliant.
Really pretty falls..but seriously dodgy rest house right beside it.
